This Company's system of submarine telegraph

communication from Egypt to Europe, North and
South America, East, South and West Africa,
India, Australia, New Zealand, China and Japan.

To secure quick transmission, telegrams should
be marked Via Eastern.

bulletin in this paper.

div.head: Peninsular and Oriental S. N. Company.
div.p: Berths can be definitely engaged as if the voyage were commencing at Port Said. Plans can be seen at the Offices of the Company's Agents.

The through Steamers for Marsailles, Gibraltar, Plymouth and London are intended to leave Port Said after the arrival of the 11 a.m. train from Cairo, every Monday. A steam tender will meet the train to convey passengers to the ship.
The Brindisi Express Steamers leave Port Said directly the Indian Mails arrive. Passengers can go on board the evening before.
The express steamer usually reaches Brindisi on Wednesday afternoon, the special train starting at 8 p.m. and arriving in London at the very convenient hour of 4.56 p.m. on Friday.
The combined Sea and special train fare is £22.9.11 Port Said to London via Brindisi or via Marseilles.
Passengers having paid full fare in one direction are allowed an abatement of 25 percent on returning within 12 months.
In addition to above regular weekly service there are sailings about twice a fortnightof 5,000 to 7,000 tons steamers to London, calling at Malta or Marseilles.
TO THE EAST

The Mail Steamers leave Suez for Aden and Bombay every Wednesday, and for Australia and China every alternate Wednesday. A steamer leaves for Calcoutta, fortnightly, and another for Japan. Passengers can embark at Port Said.
For all further information apply to the Company's Agents,
Messrs. THOS. COOK & SON (Egypt) Ltd. - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - CAIRO.
F. G. DAVIDSON, Superintendent P. & O. S. N. Company in Egypt - - - - - - - -SUEZ.

div.head: KHEDIVIAL MAIL LINE.
div.p: Express Steamers leave Alexandria every Wednesday at 4 p.m. for PIRAEUS, SMYRNA, MITYLENE, and CONSTANTINOPLE. In connection with Orient Express train-de-luxe for Vienna, Paris, and London.

Fast steamers leave Alexandria every Saturday at 6 p.m., and Port Said every Sunday at 6 p.m., for JAFFA (for Jerusalem), CAIFFA (for Nazareth), BEYROUT (for Damascus), TRIPOLI, ALEXANDRETTA, MESSINA, continuing in alternate weeks to LARNACA and LIMASSOL (Cyprus).

Steamers leave Suez weekly 6 p.m., Wednesday for Port Sudan and Saukin direct returning from Suakin evry Wednesday at noon. Every Monday at 6 p.m. a steamer leaves Suez for Jeddah continuing every other week to Suakin, Massowah, Hodbidah, Aden. Intermediate steamersdo not proceed beyond Jeddah but call at Tor, (for Sinai) El Wedj and Yambo as required.
N.B.—Deck chairs provided for the use of passengers, excellent cuisine and table wine free.
Steamer plans may be seen and passages booked at the Company’s Agencies at Alexandria, Cairo, Port Said, and Suez, or at THOS. COOK & SON or other Tourist Agency.

div.head: THE EUROPEAN OUTLOOK.
div.p: That delicate equipoise, known as the balance of power, has been sadly ont of gear since the downfall of autocracy in Russia. The most striking example of the new state of things in Europe has been the action of Germany in Morocco, and the gloominess of the outlook is fully reflected in one of the telegrams which we publish to-day. Therein we are told that a feeling of apprehension prevails throughout Europe ou the eve of the Morocco Conference, which begins this morning, and that the tone of the Spanish and Italian Press is most pessimists, while even the Berlin newspapers show an unwonted uneasiness at the rumours of Germany's military preparations. It is ridiculous to sneer at these forebodings, since the recent publication of the French Yellow Book on the Morocco question has shown to the world that Germany has within the last few months deliberately risked a most terrible European war on behalf of imaginary rights in Northern Africa, the exiguous nature of which she had already acknowledged. The history of the relations between France and Germany over the Moroccan agreement leave no doubt that the latter Power daring the month of June last was deliberately presenting a pistol to the head of its western neighbour, and that the peace of Europe was gravely endangered without the shadow of a justification. The papers in the Yellow Book begin in March 1931, and show that the anarchy in Morocco, the repeated frontier outrages, and the general ferment on the frontiers of the French possessions in North Africa were producing an absolutely intolerable state of affairs. They show also that on June 23 in that year M. Delcassé admitted to Prince Radolin that France, as mistress of Algeria and Tunis, was bound to

preserve an absolutely special position in Morocco. To this admission the German Ambassador replied, "Nothing could be fairer, everybody is in agreement on this point.” And, during the three years that followed, the best efforts of French diplomacy were devoted to the maintenance of peace in North West Africa. Of any sinister designs on her part against the integrity of Morocco or against the commercial interests of other nations in that country there is not the smallest trace. Then came the Anglo-French Agreement, which was signed on the 8th of April, 1904. Loss than a fortnight before its promulgation M. Delcassé gave an assurance to Prince Radolin that France might find it necessary to assist the Sultan in the maintenance of the political and territorial status quo in Morocco, bat that, whatever assistance was rendered, the commercial liberty of all nations interested would be rigorously respected. This declaration Prince Radolin pronounced to be quite natural and perfectly reasonable. Prince von Bulow’s acceptance of the Anglo-French Agreement, and his admission in the Reichstag that its provisions did not affect the interests if any other Power, will be well remembered.

Daring the whole of 1904, though the Pan Germanic organs began to murmur about German commercial interests being in peril, there was no official sign that the German Government harboured any resentment or felt any uneasiness at the steps which France was preparing to take in Morocco. But as the new year dawned, and as the hopelessness of the Russian entanglement in Manchuria became every day more apparent, there was a sadden change in tone. Germany professed to have discovered that she was being systematically excluded from all participation in the negotiations over Morocco. Prince von Bulow informed the German Chargé d'Affaires at Tangier “that the Imperial Government totally ignored the agreements that had been concluded as regards Morocco, and did not in any way recognise itself as bound in regard to that question.” Then came the Kaiser's journey to Tangier, and the speeches of Prince von Bulow, with which we are all familiar. These, we now learn, were supplemented by an amount of hectoring and persistent obstruction which are scarcely paralleled in the relations of Powers that are' nominally friendly. The German Chancellor left no stone untamed to represent to the French Minister of Foreign Affairs that failure to comply with German demands could have only one consequence. The Moroccan question, he declared, was “mauvaise, très mauvaise,” and he repeated that one should not linger along a road which " bordered upon a precipice, and even an abyss.” Words were used which in international relations posse is an accepted gravity far exceeding that of their usage m ordinary life. France did everything which was possible to avoid any pretext for offence; her attitude carried forbearauce to its extreme limit; finally M. Delcassé was sacrificed on the altar of German Chauvinism, and the negotiations were concluded for the Conference which is to meet to-day at Algeciras. The incident has taught the world in general, and Great Britain in particular, a lesson as to Gorman math ids which can never be forgotten.

The fact stands ont incontestably that for some days, if not for some weeks, daring the summer of 1901 we were on the verge of a conflagration between France and Germany which could not have been isolated, and must have involved sooner or later the whole of Europe. A more grievous blow against civilisation and humanity than the mere contemplation of such a catastrophe is hardly conceivable. Even now it is not apparent how it was averted, and if by any chance it should have been by the influence of England that the conflict was spared, Germany, instead of feeling any resentment, ought to harbour the deepest gratitude to the nation which preserved the peace and saved the world from an incalculable mass of human misery.

But on the contrary we need only expect that malignant hatred that is so often the lot of England because of her altruism, which foreign Powers are so utterly unable to appreciate, and we should prepare ourselves to face the worst. When, therefore, we reflect m the promptitude with which the disaster of Russia was seized upon as an opportunity for the humiliation of her ally ; whoa we consider the utter disregard of previous utterances and policy which characterise the whole of the German intervention in Morocco; and when we appreciate the light-heartedness with which Germany provokes a terrible European débâcle, it is difficult for ns to contemplate 'he future without apprehension and to look forward to the conference, who e sittings begin this morning, without a certain amount of alarm.

div.head: LOCAL AND GENERAL.
div.p: Military Tournament.
The Royal Military Tournament will take place on the 31at inst. at Ghezireh.
The Brindisi Mail.
The mail will close at the G. P. 0., Alexandria, at 3.10 p.m. on Sunday.
National Hotel,
The Bracale orchestra will play for dinner at the National Hotel, Cairo, on Saturday.
Revue d'Egypte et d'Orient.
The December issue of this excellent little local publication is as foil and as interesting as its predecessors.
Red Sea Lighthouses.
We have received a parcel of literature from Mr. R. Kuster for the use of the English keepers of the Red Sea lighthouses.
Anniversaries.
To-day is the twentieth anniversary of the fall of Omdurman. On the 5th January, 1899. the Gordon College was founded at Khartoum.
A Red Sea Find.
A new species of worm has been discovered lately on the shores of the Red Sea. It is a Pontodrilus.
Cinema Parisien.
By request, there will until further notice be two exhibitions of the Cinema Parisien, from 5 to 8 p.m. and from 9 p.m. to midnight, without interruption.
New Khédivial Hotel.
The new wing of the New Khédivial Hotel, Alexandria, is now fini-bed and is being furnished. Thirty rooms are now ready and a total of sixty new rooms will be ready in two months’ time.
General Holidays.

All Government Departments and offices will be closed on the 8th inst., on the occasion of the anniversary of the Khedive’s accession, and on the 11th inst., on the occasion of the departure, of the Mahmal.
Pilgrim Hospital.

The Sultan has ordered a hospital of 120 beds to be constructed at Ma’àn, on the Hedjaz railway. A building is to be commenced immediately and meantime a tent hospital will supply the needs of the garrison and of the pilgrims.
Transport.

The transport Sicilia, which is due at Port Said on the 9th inst., will embark a number of details of the Army of Occupation for passage to England. Those from Alexandria will leave by the 3.40 p.m. train and those from Cairo by the 6.15 p.m. train on the 8th inst.
The Egyptian Elephant.

There is a highly interesting account in Professor Ray Lankester’s new book on extinct animals of the history of the elephant as disclosed. by the remarkable fossils discovered in recent years by Dr. Andrews and Mr. Beadnell, in the Eocene deposits of the Fayoum district, and known as Palæomastodon and Meri therium, the latter representing a very early ancestral type, a rather pig-like animal, yet foreshadowing in many ways the elephant to be.
Coptic Manuscripts.

A catalogue of the Coptic Manuscripts in the British Museum has been published by Mr. W. E. Crum. The collection described in this catalogue consists of MSS. in the Sa’idic, Middle Egyptian, and Bohairic dialects of Coptic. Of these, the first group comes mainly from the White Monastery at Ahmin, the second mainly from the Fayoum, and the third from the Nitrian monasteries. This is the first published catalogue which embraces MSS., both literary and non-literary, in all these idioms.

div.head: OBITUARY.
div.p: GEORGE OGILVY HAIG.

Mr. George Ogilvy Haig, who died on Sunday week, was greatly interested in Egyptian mining. He was a director of the Egyptian Gold and Gem Syndicate Limited, and of the Egyptian Sudan Minerals, Limited, and was well known in Cairo. He died at Chester under very sad circumstances. Mr. and Mrs. Haig left 65, Brook-street on Saturday afternoon to spend Christmas with Mr. Haig’s sister in Dublin, breaking the journey at Chester. That night Mr. Haig felt unwell, but there wore no serious symptoms until he was dressing in the morning, when ptomaine poisoning declared itself in a most virulent form, and in two hours he was dead.

Mr. George Haig was the fourth son of Mr. John Haig, of Cameron Bridge, Fife, N B. He married nine years ago the daughter of the late Mr. William Astor, of New York. His youngest brother is General Douglas Haig. The Haigs belong to the well-known Haigs of Bemerside, of whom Thomas the Rhymer in the thirteenth century prophesied, “Tyde what may betyde, Haig shall be Haig of Bemerside.” So far the prophecy bus been fulfilled, and, considering the size and affluence of the family, there is no sign as yet of any failure of fulfilment.

div.head: CHINESE LABOUR IN THE RAND.
div.p: London, Friday, Jan. 5,

It is reported that Lord Selborne, High Commissioner for South Africa, stated that if his signature to the pending contracts for the importation of Chinese into the Rand are not honoured by the Imperial Government he will resign his Office. Lord Elgin has agreed to the contracts being fulfilled.

div.head: ARMY REFORM.
div.p: London, Friday, Jan. 5.

Mr. Haldane, the new Secretary for War, delivered a speech in the City last night in which he raised the question of the Army outside the sphere of party politics. The speech which was a frank acknowledgment that there was room for improvement and contained a suggestion that he intended to do for the Army what Admiral Fisher hid done for the Navy, on reconstruction lines which would bring it up to the highest quality of efficiency and mobility, and his response to the spirit of the Volunteers, mark him as a statesman of the first class.

div.head: MINISTRY OF JUSTICE.
div.p: The Budget of the Ministry of Justice, which in 1905 was fixed at LE 504,200, has been railed to L.E. 534.737, showing an increase of LE 80,537. Of this increase, L.E. 13,103 is attributable to the Mixed Tribunals, and L.E 16,142 to the Native Tribunals.

There is an increase of L.E. 584 in the expenses of Central Administration. A new post of interpreter bas been created in view of the increasing amount of English work; some increases of salary have been granted.

Under the beading of Mixed Tribunals the increase is mainly attributable t) the creation of new posts, and to the arrangement instituted in 1905, by which the 2 % fee to greffiers and the travelling expenses of huissiers are no longer deducted from the receipts of the tribunals.
Provision has been made for the appoint ment of an additional native Judge of the Court of Appeal.

An additional foreign Judge of First Instance will also be appointed, end will be attached to the Tribunal of Alexandria The Budget of 1905 provided for 11 Judges of First Instance for Cairo, and 11 for Alexandria: but it has been found absolutely necessary to attach 12 Judges to the Cairo Tribunal, and there have thus been only 10 available for Alexandria. Experience has shown that another Judge at Alexandria is needed.

The increased volume of business coming before the Tribunals of Cairo and Alexandria has necessitated a corresponding increase in the number of employés attached to those tribunals, and over 30 new posts have been created.

The amount allowed in the Budget of 1905 for expenses formerly paid directly ont of the receipts of the tribunals has been found to be insufficient, and an increase of LE 3,569 is granted on this account
The pay of "hors cadre” employés has been raised.

The system of Native Assize Courts has now been in operation in Cairo and Lower Egypt fir nearly a year, and appears to be a decided success The system will be extended to Upper Egypt from the beginning of 1906, and provision has been made for meeting the cost of his extension. An additional native Judge of the Court of Appeal will be appointed, and will be available for Assize work; the extension will necessitate a considerable increase in the costs of transport travelling allowances and indemnities of the Judges, and additional copying clerks have to be engaged.

The salaries of the Avocat-Général and of the European Inspectors of the Parquet bave been raised, and an additional native Inspector of the Parquet will be appointed. The work required of the medical expert attached to the Parquet has become too heavy for one man, and provision is made for the appointment of an assistant.

As in the case of tin Mixed Tribunals, it has been found that the sum allotted for expenses formerly paid directly out of receipts is insufficient: an additional sum of LE 6,500 has been provided to meet these expenses.

div.head: NEW DOCTORS' FEES.
div.p: LAST NIGHT'S MEETING.
MASS MEETING TO BE HELD.

Yesterday evening, as announced, a meeting was held at Alexandria to protest against the enormous increase in the fees of medical practitioners, as decreed by the recent decision of the Medical Council of Alexandria. There was a fair attendance of persons and a number of speeches were made on the subject of the hardships which this increase will inflict on the poorer classes of the community, especially in the case of the inhabitants of the city itself, where the fees have been doubled, from 5 francs to 10 francs for each visit to the doctor. It was eventually decided to summon another meeting for Friday next, when the following propositions will be discussed and put to the vote:
That a committee shall be appointed with a view to interviewing the members of the Medical Council of Alexandria and pointing out to those gentlemen the injustice of their recent decision.

That a mass meeting should be organised, to be held in a local theatre, for the purpose of protesting on behalf of all the inhabitants of Alexandria and Ramleh against the extortions of local medical practitioners.

div.head: THE DIPHTHERIA EPIDEMIC AT ZEITOUN.
div.p: Drs. Bitter and Dreyer have made an interesting official statement relating to the outbreak of diphtheria at Zeitoun. It appears that the first case was reported on December 23, when a child died. Three more cases were noted on the 28th, and Drs. Dreyer and d'Andrea visited all cases reported and inoculated children who were known to have been in contact with the three children actually ill, who were also inoculated with serum. In one case the remedy came too late, the other two are now convalescent. On the following day seven new cases were reported, six of which proved fatal. No cases were reported after January 1, the total death-roll amounting to eight out of twelve cases.

The anti-toxin employed was fresh Behring serum, which is universally regarded as the best in existence. Rigorous measures have been taken to prevent the spread of the epidemic and the schools will be closed till farther notice.

div.head: CATTLE PLAGUE.
div.p: Several very auspicious ewes of bovine typhus have been reported from the Fayoum, but were promptly dealt with by the Veterinary Department of the Public Health Administration.

div.head: NEW HOSPITAL AT GALIOUB
div.p: Mohamed Shawarby Pacha, a member of tin Legislative Council and a wealthy notable of Galioubish province, has built a hospital at Galioub at his own expense. He has spent over L.E 5,000 on the building and endowed the hospital with 200 feddans of land, which will yield an income of from L.E. 1,500 to LE. 2,000 per annum. The Pacha has informed the Sanitary Department of the completion of the building. The new hospital will be officially opened shortly.

div.head: FINANCIAL ADVISER’S NOTE.
div.p: THE SPECULATION BOGEY.
CRITICISMS BY OUR READERS.
TO THE EDITOR OF THE EGYPTIAN GAZETTE.

Sir,—"An Admirer of the British Administration” strikes the right nail on the head in pointing oat that the notes of warning constancy sounded by our administrators have the effect of keeping out of Egypt only the British investor; I however think that he might have worded his protest more strongly. No doubt in a measure the prosperity of Egypt is due to the wise administration of Lord Cromer, and more so to the able Irrigation engineers who have greatly improved our water supply, but after all is said and done, the real factors are the wonderful fertility or the soil and the untiring industry of the fellah.

The Press of England in the first instance, and latterly that of the world, has so extolled our British administrators that they in their turn have been brought to believe they are beings beyond or out of, the common order of humanity, competent to express an infallible opinion on any and every subject, hence as a result these grandmotherly efforts which are periodically made to pat down what they consider gambling or over-speculation, which only succeed in adversely affecting legitimate business for a short time.

The European community in Egypt being small, ever one knows what everybody is doing, consequently if any lucky Government official possessing a small amount of capital and the sense to invest it in local securities, makes a legitimate profit, the news speedily circulates and our high administrators shake their wise heads and say "we mast put a stop to gambling md speculation.”

"Admirer is quite right when he says that there is less commercial gambling in Egypt than in most countries, but he is wrong in attributing this to the want of a ‘''term market” in stocks and shares, the reason is that there are and have been daring the past few years and will continue to exist for many years to come, plenty of opportunities of making handsome profits by purchasing lands both agricultural and building, stocks and shares, and hiding the same for a rapid and legitimate rise consequently the inducement to gamble is lacking.
The only inflated value in Egypt is perhaps the estimation in which some of our worthy administrators hold themselves. — I beg to remain, Sir, etc.,
"ANGLO-EGYPTIAN.”
Cairo, January 4.

div.head: TO THE EDITOR OF THE EGYPTIAN GAZETTE
div.p: Will your correspondent who writes under the name of "An Admirer of the British Administration in Egypt” kindly mention the names of a tow towns of lees importance than Cairo or Alexandria where values of building sites are higher than in those named above? It "Admirer” is right which I very much doubt, it will be the duty of the Financial Adviser to withdraw the sweeping assertions made in his Budget Note, but until that is proved I think Sir Vincent Corbett has rendered a public service in warning the unsuspecting British Public against the Egyptian land speculator who is baying up at unheard-of priors every available plot of land.—I am, Sir, etc.
"FAIR PLAY”
Cairo, 4th January.

div.head: NATIVE FEELING.
div.p: AN ALARMIST VIEWPOINT.
To THE EDITOR OF THE EGYPTIAN GAZETTE.

Sir,—Since the recent trouble at Alexandria I have endeavoured by various methods to ascertain what feeling, if any, exists in the provinces are to an anti-Christian movement. It is obvions that any attempt of this sort on the part of a foreigner and a Christian is-fraught with many difficulties, and that anyone looking for trouble might imagine he had found it where none really existed. In common with meet people who live and work in the provinces I was strongly of opinion that no danger was to be looked for from the fellaheen and lashed class generally, but I regret to say I have bad to alter my opinion.

I find that the “barb el deen” is the one topic of conversation among them. The younger men are faying “Why should we wait for the order; let us begin.” The older men who look to the Sultan say, "Wait, he will give the word when all is ready.” They know all about the trouble in Macedonia and they believe that the faith is in danger in Morocco and that the time is come to make one last decisive stand against ever-encroaching Christianity.

They reason thus. Against Alexandria we cannot do ouch as there are English ships which we cannot do much and they are land many men, but at Cairo, where there are many Christians and few soldiers, we can do much, and even if the go to extremes we shall be able eventually to make them give in and so compel then to leave the country, and in the provinces we can do what we like. When all the Mohamedan world is fighting the last great fight for the faith how shall the Christians overcome us, will not God and the Prophet give us the victory?

This, Sir I affirm, is the state of affairs at the present moment, bat the spark that shall start the blaze is happily lacking at the time. But when the spark is kindled the conflagration will not be a small one. The less that is said and the more precautions that are taken in an affair of this sort the better. — Yours, etc.,
"PROVINCIAL."

div.head: SUCRIES ET RAFFINERIE D'EGYPTE
div.p: ASSEMBLÉE GÉNÉRALE DES OBLIGATAIRES
(Suite et fin de la discussion.)

UN OBLIGATAIRE. — Je commence d’abord par remercier le Comité d’avoir rejeté le projet des contrôleur,», contraire à nos intérêts. Et j’entre dans la question des poursuites envers les administrateurs. M. Lacombe disait tont A l’heare qne l'Association Nationale ne pouvait pas soutenir les actions individuelles Ce pointr me semble juste. Mais l’Association a été créée pour soutenir l’intérét des porteurs. Il y a ici nn oas général : c'ait celui des escroqueries et des vols oommis b notre détriment, qui sont justiciables de la juridiction correctionnelle. L’Assooiation pourrait se joindre an groupe d'actionnaires qui a déposé une plainte an parqneb Et si leparqnetet le Juge d'ins traction déclarent oonpables les administrateurs, nous pourrons nous porter partie civile, et l’Assooia tien pourra nous réanir pour payer notre part de cotisation afin de p ycr les poursuites.
None pourrons alors faire valoir individuel lament nos droits à la réparation du préjudice causé.

Je orois que la Société Générale pourrait être rendue responsable, tout au moins en la personne de son Directeur. Ses employés ont donné des renseignements inexacts, et le? tribunaux pourraient examiner jusqu’à quel point la Sooiété Générale est responsable do ses représentants.
On nous a parlé de noos accorder 2 %. J’estime qne si nous sommes obligés do faite nn sacrifice, il devrait être au maximum do 100 francs par obligation, payable de la manière suivante :

Les obligations actuelles seraient transformées en obligations 3 % 400 francs, avec première hypothèque sur tout l'actif social, à l’exception des domaines achetés à la Daira Sanieh. Au cas oh la Société serait remise sur pied, il nous serait donné une action de 100 francs, qui prendrait rang aprè» les actions actuelles. L’amortissement serait suspendn pendant cinq ans. J'estime que c'est là le maximum de concessions que nous pourrons faire.
UN OBLIGATAIRE — Quelle serait la situation des Obligataires, en admettant qu’il y ait faillite t Quels avantages pourrions-nous retirer d'un arrangementlQue pourrions noos toucher!
M. LACOUBE — C'est là, en effa', la queition la plus importante et on pourrait la qualifier de préjudiciable ; je vais y répondre.

Il y a un point sur lequel je me proposai» d’être robre de détails, parce que je ne voulais pas fournir des arguments à ceux qui vans pré senteraient nn projet d'arrangement onéreox : c'e«t celui des coneéquenoes probables de 1a faillite.

Vous pavez œ qu’est une usine à sucre. Elle peut valoir beauooup, mais seulement à la condition qoel'oh pourra continuer la fabrication, car si l'industrie doit cesser, il faut vendre les bâtiments à un prix inférieur, et les appareils et machines se vendront également au prix du vieux matériel. Si les experts ont pu les évaluer h on prix assez élevé, c’est dans la prévision qu'elles continueraient à fonctionner.

Sans doute, si oes usines étaient dans la ré gion dn t ord de la Frapoe, on pourrait espérer trouver toojonrs nn acqoéreor à nn prix rai sonnable. En Egypte, il n'y a pas à prévoir de oonourrence entre acquéreurs. Si vous ne faites pas nn concordat qni poisse assurer le relèvement de l’affaire, vous verrez que l’aotif serv aobeté à vil prix par nn groupe qui réalisera de» bénéfices énormes au préjudice des oréan oiers actuels.

Ce qu’il importe, avant tont, ce n’est pas tant oe qn'on promettra aux obligataires par le oonoordat, o’est ce qu'il adviendra de l’affaire Le Comité s'est donc préoonppé principalement de ce qni pouvait assurer nne sérieuse réorganisation. Le projet présenté par la Société ne Ini donne pas à ce point de vue de garanties suffisantes; car l’Adminis ration resterait entre les mains d'actionnaires qni n'ont pas d'in’érêt à bien gérer. Voilà pourquoi, dès le premier jour, nous avons appnyé, sauf à l’amender snr oertains points, le projet de reconstitution q i émane d’> n groupe financier sérieox.

D’après ce projet, à vous Obligataires, on donnera des obligations à revenu variable mais l’affaire sera réorganisée, et s’appuiera désormais, snr le groupe des porteurs d’actions privilégiées, groupe qui comprendra les plus grandes maisons financières de Paris.
DES VOIX. — Lesquelles 1

M. LACOMBE — Ce sont les porteurs de traite dont je parle ; vous savez qne, parmi eux se trouvent plusieurs barques de premier ordre. Ces futurs actionnaires se trouvent dans uno telle situation, que, l-r-qne U Société aura besoin de fonds, i's n’auront pas de peili1' à trouver les conooors nécessaire?. Parmi eux, je otnprenda la Sociéré Générale elle même, et il est à souhaiter qne le groupe de la Daira Sugar figure parmi ces ooncours, parce qo cela augmentera les chance» qne voua avez d’obtenir dn Gouvernement Egyptien les oon cesMnnn qne nous attendons de lui.
UN Obligataire - Le contrat de la Daira Su car est-il valable 1

M. LACOMBE — Notre avocat du Caire nous l’a dée’aré tel. Mais, de tonte façon, il taot i’iv cepter, car la reconstitution de l’affaire repose, en grande partie, sur des concessions du G luvornement Egyptien, qne vous obt'edrft pins f cilemrnt si l'élément anglo-égyptien est , inlériM-é à l'entreprise.

Four qne le service des obligations soit ii Miré, que faut-il f Un bénéfice de 3,200,000 fr par an. Nous pensons qu'aveole? oonronrs dont nous parlons, r-e chiffre pourra être obtenu ; en tons cas, affirmer que d'ici quelques années il ■ e le sera pas, o'eat tffi-mor une chose que l’on ni sait pas. Quoi qu’il en soit, l'ix érience j na rao'.el.'e pas la peine d’ê're tentée? Evi- d u nnnt si, et LOUS ne v yons pas pourquoi foui ne e f.riez pat, puisqu'elle ne vont fait

pas perdre vos rcconrs et que vous seriez toujours à temps de les faire valoir, peut-être même avec d autant plus de force que vous aurez fait tout votre possible pour restreindre Il préjudice éprouvé.

UN Obligataire. — De qui émane le deu- x'ème projet I Est il officieux on officiel 1 A-t il des ohances d'aboutir i M. Lacoube. — Il est officieux ; il émane d’un groupe financier, notamment dn groupe anglo-égyptien dont il a été parlé. Nos pourparlers arec la Société tendent à faire substituer œ projet à l’autre comme base de discussion. Nos raisons nous paraissent tellement convaincantes, que nous croyons avoir de eé rieuses chance» d’aboutir à co premier résultat.
UN Obligataire. — Avant de passer au vote, voudriez vous relire le projet officieux ?

M. LACOMBE — Ce projet dit qo’il sera fait nne émission d’ob'igatiom hypothécaires de 800.000 livres ; les obligations actuelles seront réduites de 20 % et deviendront variables. Les porteurs de traites, recevant dos notions privilégiées, ne viendraient pas en concurrence avec Iss Obligataires. Pendant les trois premières années, il serait servi à ces derniers un intérêt fixe garanti de dix franos. Il est vrai qn’on ne nous a offert jusqu’ici que 7 fr. 50.
UN Obligataire — Les Obligataires au raient-ils le droit de préférence dans la souscription des nouvelles obligations bypothé caires ?

M. LACOMBE. — S’il est réclamé, il sera sans doute volontiers aooordé. Au sujet de la réduction du capital nominal des obligations, tonten maintenant leur intérêt et leur amortissement au taux aotuel, ce n'est qu'uue question de omptab lité tendant à équilibrer le bilan La durée de l'amortissement est fixée à 50 ans.

Nous faisons tous nos efforts poor ramener la Société à ce projet, autant pour éviter anx Obligataires, la concurrence des porteurs de traites, q .’afin de pouvoir compter sur eux pour assurer à l’affaire une bonne direction.

UN Obligataire. — Aurons-nous une qnote part de fonds provenant de la vente Cronier t M. Lacombe — Noua n'avons pu étndié spécialement cette question. On ne pourrait enc .re former saisie-arrêt sur cette somme ; il faudrait d’abord obteuir ud j ugement constatant le droit de oréanoe. C’est nue question dont le Comité pourra se préoccuper.
Un OBLIGATAIRE' — Le Comité ne pourrait- il pu inviter les représentants de 1a Sooiété en Egypte à faire oette saisie ?
M. LACOMBE. — Le Comité soumettra cetta question à ses Conseils dn Caire.
Un OBLIGATAIRE. — Je me demande s'il n'y aurait pas intérêt à envisager la possibilité d'nDe liquidation ?

Notre Comité devrait faire étudier la question de savoir si l'on ne pourrait pu obtenir des Tribunaux égyptiens de nous faire passer avant les porteurs de traites ? Dans le cas contraire, nous aurions intérêt à dire : si les porteurs de traites ne veulent pu faire un sacrifice beaucoup plus grand que celui qu’on nous demande, tant pis pour eux, et l'on procédera à la liquidation.

M. LACOMBE. — Nous avons posé cette question de droit commercial égyptien à M. Saint- Plancat, qui nous a répondu qu’il n'y avait pu légalement de difiérenoes entre les porteurs de traites et les Obligataires, sous réserve de l'examen de choque oréanoe devant le Tribunal. Mais, en dehors du droit striot, il y a les pourparlers amiables, grâce auxquels nous espérons pouvoir faire passer les porteurs de traites après tes Obligataires.

Un Obligataire. — Pour que nous puissions exercer faction sociale ou les actions individuelles dont on a parlé tont à l’hsure, et pour pouvoir nous grouper dans ce but, il importe que nous nous connaissions. Je deman de donc qu’nne liste des adhérants nous soit communiquée par l’Assoeiation,

M. LACOMBE. - ,’edois dire que l’Association a déclaré expr esté ment, lors de sa fondation, que pour tous les renreiguements qui lui seraient donnés par les porteurs sur les valeurs qa'ils possèdent, elle se considérait oomme tenue par le secret professionnel.

M. LE PRESIDENT. — La discussion étant terminée, et vu l'impossibilité de prendre nne décision défiuitive en oe moment sur les propositions concordataires, je vous invite à voter simplemeut les trois résolutions suivantes :

Ire RESOLUTION Les Ooligataires de la Société Générale des Sucreries et de la Raffinerie d’Egypte réunis en Assemblée Générale par les soins de Association Nationale des porteurs Français de valeurs étrangères approuvent le rapport présenté par la Comité de Défense et invitent le Comité à continuer ses démarches en vne d’arriver à un accord snr les bases et sous réserve des amendements indiqués au rapport.
Cette résolution est votée à l’unanimité moins cinq voix.
2me RESOLUTION

Les obligataires approuvant les démarches déjà faites auprès du Gouvernement Françria, invitent l’Association Nationale et le Comité de Défmse à les otntiuuer, en vue d’obtenir du Gouvernement Egyptien l’adoption des mesures les plus propres à favoriser le relèvement de ,'inluscrie sucrière en Egypte.
3me RESOLUTION

L’Assemblée invite le Comité à transmettre immédiatement à M. le Juge-Commis, Présidant de U Chambre Commerciale dn Caire, les résolutions de l’Assemblée et à lni demander d’ao- oorder les délais suffisants pour permettre aux négociations de se poursuivre.
Ces deux dernières résolutions sont votées a l’onaoimité.
